info.title: Neuroblastoma (NBL) Data Dictionary
info.name: nbl_v1.2
info.description: The NBL data dictionary is a consensus data schema built by an international group of pediatric neuroblastoma experts and maintained by Data for the Common Good (D4CG) at the University of Chicago in collaboration with the International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG). It is based on the collective requirements of its contributors.

HONEST_BROKER_SUBJECT_ID.description: The identifier assigned to the subject by the honest broker--an individual, organization or system acting for, or on behalf of, a covered entity to collect and provide health information to research investigators in such a manner whereby it would not be reasonably possible for the investigators or others to identify the corresponding patients-subjects directly or indirectly. The honest broker cannot be one of the investigators. The information provided to the investigators by the honest broker may incorporate linkage codes to permit information collation and/or subsequent inquiries (i.e., a "re-identification code"), however the information linking this re-identification code to the patient's identity must be retained by the honest broker and subsequent inquiries are conducted through the honest broker.

AGE_AT_ENROLLMENT.description: The age (in days) when the subject enrolled in the study.

YEAR_AT_ENROLLMENT.description: The year at which a subject enrolled in a study.

STUDY_ID.description: A sequence of characters used to identify, name, or characterize the study.
implementation_notes: ConsortiumNote: Some patients will have frontline data already in PCDC, we want to link rather than duplicate data for these patients.

TREATMENT_ARM.description: A specific treatment plan within a clinical trial that describes the activities a subject will be involved in as he or she progresses through the study.

AGE_AT_CENSOR_STATUS.description: The age (in days) of the subject at the time of the event censor status.

EFS_CENSOR_STATUS.description: The status of individuals in a study when their outcome (event occurrence or time to event) is censored or not censored at the time of analysis or data collection. Censoring occurs when an individual has not experienced the event of interest by the end of the study period or at the time of data analysis, often because they were lost to follow-up, withdrew from the study, or the study ended before the event could occur. In event-free survival analysis, these censored individuals are included in the analysis up to the point of censoring and are essential for estimating survival probabilities and analyzing the time to events.

Subject is censored (i.e. has had no eve.description: The status of a participant or subject in a study whose event or outcome of interest has not yet occurred or has not been observed within the study's follow-up period. Censoring occurs when the event of interest has not happened to a participant by the end of the study or when they are lost to follow-up before the event occurs.

Subject has had one or more events.description: The patient has experienced the event of interest within the study period and has reached the endpoint being evaluated, such as disease progression, relapse, recurrence, or death, and their time to event can be accurately recorded and analyzed.

HONEST_BROKER_SUBJECT_ID.description: The identifier assigned to the subject by the honest broker--an individual, organization or system acting for, or on behalf of, a covered entity to collect and provide health information to research investigators in such a manner whereby it would not be reasonably possible for the investigators or others to identify the corresponding patients-subjects directly or indirectly. The honest broker cannot be one of the investigators. The information provided to the investigators by the honest broker may incorporate linkage codes to permit information collation and/or subsequent inquiries (i.e., a "re-identification code"), however the information linking this re-identification code to the patient's identity must be retained by the honest broker and subsequent inquiries are conducted through the honest broker.

DISEASE_PHASE.description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

Initial Diagnosis.description: The first diagnosis of the individual's condition.

Relapse/Progression.description: Either the return of the disease or the progression of the disease.

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.description: The number of the disease phase.

AGE_AT_DISEASE_PHASE.description: Age of subject (in days) at the end of the treatment course.

YEAR_AT_DISEASE_PHASE.description: Age of subject (in days) at the disease phase.

HONEST_BROKER_SUBJECT_ID.description: The identifier assigned to the subject by the honest broker--an individual, organization or system acting for, or on behalf of, a covered entity to collect and provide health information to research investigators in such a manner whereby it would not be reasonably possible for the investigators or others to identify the corresponding patients-subjects directly or indirectly. AGE_AT_CYCLE_START.description: Age in Days at Cycle Start
implementation_notes: ConsortiumNote: Only available for trail therapy, not for frontline

AGE_AT_CYCLE_END.description: Age in Days at Cycle End
implementation_notes: ConsortiumNote: Only available for trail therapy, not for frontline

SEX.description: The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female.

Male.description: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.

Female.description: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces ova. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, or cultural gender role distinctions, or both.

Unknown.description: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

HONEST_BROKER_SUBJECT_ID.description: The identifier assigned to the subject by the honest broker--an individual, organization or system acting for, or on behalf of, a covered entity to collect and provide health information to research investigators in such a manner whereby it would not be reasonably possible for the investigators or others to identify the corresponding patients-subjects directly or indirectly. AGE_AT_LKSS.description: The age (in days) when the last known survival status of the subject was captured.

DISEASE_PHASE.description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

Relapse/Progression.description: Either the return of the disease or the progression of the disease.

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.description: The number of the disease phase.

LKSS.description: The last known survival status of the subject.

Alive.description: Showing characteristics of life; displaying signs of life.

CAUSE_OF_DEATH.description: The circumstance or condition that results in the death of a living being.

Treatment-Related Mortality.description: A death that is considered to be causally linked to a treatment.

HONEST_BROKER_SUBJECT_ID.description: The identifier assigned to the subject by the honest broker--an individual, organization or system acting for, or on behalf of, a covered entity to collect and provide health information to research investigators in such a manner whereby it would not be reasonably possible for the investigators or others to identify the corresponding patients-subjects directly or indirectly. The honest broker cannot be one of the investigators. The information provided to the investigators by the honest broker may incorporate linkage codes to permit information collation and/or subsequent inquiries (i.e., a "re-identification code"), however the information linking this re-identification code to the patient's identity must be retained by the honest broker and subsequent inquiries are conducted through the honest broker.

AGE_AT_TUMOR_ASSESSMENT.description: Age of subject (in days) at tumor assessment.

DISEASE_PHASE.description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

Initial Diagnosis.description: The first diagnosis of the individual's condition.

Relapse/Progression.description: Either the return of the disease or the progression of the disease.

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.description: The number of the disease phase.

TUMOR_CLASSIFICATION.description: The classification of a tumor based primarily on histopathological characteristics.

Primary.description: A tumor at the original site of origin.

Metastatic.description: A tumor that has spread from its original (primary) site of growth to another site, close to or distant from the primary site.  Metastasis is characteristic of advanced malignancies, but in rare instances can be seen in neoplasms lacking malignant morphology.

TUMOR_STATE.description: A condition or state of a tumor at a particular time and a particular tumor site.

Present.description: Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Absent.description: Not existing in a specified place at a specified time.

Unknown.description: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

TUMOR_SITE.description: The anatomic site of the tumor.

Central Nervous System.description: The part of the nervous system that consists of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.

Distant Lymph Nodes.description: A lymph node located distant to the anatomic site of interest.

Liver.description: A triangular-shaped organ located under the diaphragm in the right hypochondrium. It is the largest internal organ of the body, weighting up to 2 kg. Metabolism and bile secretion are its main functions. It is composed of cells which have the ability to regenerate.

Lung.description: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Adrenal Gland.description: A flattened, roughly triangular body resting upon the upper end of each kidney; it is one of the ductless glands furnishing internal secretions (epinephrine and norepinephrine from the medulla and steroid hormones from the cortex).

Abdomen.description: The cavity located between the lungs and pelvis. It contains the lower esophagus, stomach, pancreas, intestines, liver, gallbladder and spleen.

Neck.description: The region that connects the head to the rest of the body.

Thorax.description: The division of the body lying between the neck and the abdomen.

Pelvis.description: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.

Bone Marrow.description: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

Bone.description: The structural organ comprised of specialized connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.

Skin.description: An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.

HONEST_BROKER_SUBJECT_ID.description: The identifier assigned to the subject by the honest broker--an individual, organization or system acting for, or on behalf of, a covered entity to collect and provide health information to research investigators in such a manner whereby it would not be reasonably possible for the investigators or others to identify the corresponding patients-subjects directly or indirectly. DISEASE_PHASE.description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

Initial Diagnosis.description: The first diagnosis of the individual's condition.

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.description: The number of the disease phase.

STAGE.description: The extent of a cancer in the body. Staging is usually based on the size of the tumor, whether lymph nodes contain cancer, and whether the cancer has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

HONEST_BROKER_SUBJECT_ID.description: The identifier assigned to the subject by the honest broker--an individual, organization or system acting for, or on behalf of, a covered entity to collect and provide health information to research investigators in such a manner whereby it would not be reasonably possible for the investigators or others to identify the corresponding patients-subjects directly or indirectly. The honest broker cannot be one of the investigators. The information provided to the investigators by the honest broker may incorporate linkage codes to permit information collation and/or subsequent inquiries (i.e., a "re-identification code"), however the information linking this re-identification code to the patient's identity must be retained by the honest broker and subsequent inquiries are conducted through the honest broker.

AGE_AT_MOLECULAR_ANALYSIS.description: Age of subject (in days) when molecular analysis was performed.

DISEASE_PHASE.description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

Initial Diagnosis.description: The first diagnosis of the individual's condition.

Relapse/Progression.description: Either the return of the disease or the progression of the disease.

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.description: The number of the disease phase.

MOLECULAR_ABNORMALITY.description: The type of variation detected by this genetic analysis.

MYCN Amplification.description: An increase in the number of copies of the MYCN gene, resulting in the overexpression of the MYCN protein. MYCN amplification is commonly associated with aggressive neuroblastoma and can be a predictor of poor prognosis and a target for specific therapies.

GENE1.description: The gene symbol that represents either a single gene that has a mutation or the gene that comprises the 5' portion of the coding sequence involved in a fusion gene mutation.

COPY_NUMBER_STATUS.description: The status of the copy number.

Gain.description: The acquisition of additional copies of a specific DNA segment, which can include entire chromosomes or smaller DNA regions. In the context of cancer, gains often refer to the increase in the number of copies of chromosomal regions or genes, which can lead to overexpression and tumor development.

Loss.description: The decrease in the number of copies of a specific DNA segment, which can include entire chromosomes or smaller chromosomal regions. This can occur through deletions, where a segment of DNA is removed, or through other mechanisms that result in reduced genetic material. Loss of genetic material can lead to the absence of essential genes, loss of gene function, or reduced gene dosage, which can contribute to disease development, including cancer.

Amplification.description: Amplification refers to an increase in the number of copies of a specific DNA segment, which can include genes or chromosomal regions. This genetic alteration results in the overproduction of the gene or genes located within the amplified region. In cancer, gene amplification can lead to the overexpression of oncogenes, which can drive tumor growth and contribute to cancer progression. Amplification is typically identified through genetic testing techniques such as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), quantitative PCR, or array-based methods.

No gain/loss/amplification.description: A genetic variation where gain, loss, or exchange of DNA results in monoallelic loss of function mutations in a diploid cell. In the context of tumor suppressor genes, where a single copy is sufficient for functionality, loss of function for the second allele is associated with tumorigenesis.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

HONEST_BROKER_SUBJECT_ID.description: The identifier assigned to the subject by the honest broker--an individual, organization or system acting for, or on behalf of, a covered entity to collect and provide health information to research investigators in such a manner whereby it would not be reasonably possible for the investigators or others to identify the corresponding patients-subjects directly or indirectly. The honest broker cannot be one of the investigators. The information provided to the investigators by the honest broker may incorporate linkage codes to permit information collation and/or subsequent inquiries (i.e., a "re-identification code"), however the information linking this re-identification code to the patient's identity must be retained by the honest broker and subsequent inquiries are conducted through the honest broker.

AGE_AT_SMN.description: Age in Days at Secondary Malignant Neoplasm

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.description: The number of the disease phase.

Yes.description: The affirmative response to a question.

No.description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

DISEASE_PHASE.description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

Initial Diagnosis.description: The first diagnosis of the individual's condition.

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.description: The number of the disease phase.

SCT_TYPE.description: The type of stem cell transplant that the subject received.

Autologous, Single.description: An autologous stem cell transplant performed once. In this procedure, a patient's own stem cells are collected, stored, and then reinfused after intensive chemotherapy or radiation therapy. The purpose is to restore the bone marrow and blood cell production that the aggressive treatment has destroyed.

Autologous, Tandem.description: A series of two autologous stem cell transplants performed sequentially, usually within a few months of each other. The tandem transplant approach is designed to maximize the therapeutic effect of high-dose chemotherapy or radiation by repeating the stem cell reinfusion process, offering a more aggressive treatment option for certain cancers.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Yes.description: The affirmative response to a question.

No.description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

PROCEDURE.description: A categorization of surgical procedures by type or purpose.

AGE_AT_RESPONSE.description: Age of subject (in days) when the response assessment was made.

DISEASE_PHASE.description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

Relapse/Progression.description: Either the return of the disease or the progression of the disease.

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.description: The number of the disease phase.

RESPONSE_CATEGORY.description: The category used to assess the response to therapy.

Overall Response.description: An assessment of the overall response of the disease to the therapy.

Primary Site Response.description: The response at a primary site of a disease or condition to treatment.

Bone Marrow Response.description: The response of the bone marrow to the treatment.

Metastatic Soft Tissue and Bone Response.description: The evaluation of how metastatic (spreading) cancer affects and responds to treatment in soft tissues and bones. Metastatic cancer cells originate from the primary tumor and spread to other parts of the body, including soft tissues (like muscles, fat, and connective tissues) and bones. The response can be assessed through imaging studies, biopsies, and other diagnostic tests to determine changes in tumor size, density, and metabolic activity in these areas, which helps guide treatment decisions and prognosis.

RESPONSE.description: A standard way to measure how well a cancer patient responds to treatment.

Not Done.description: Indicates a task, process or examination that has either not been initiated or not been completed.

Unknown.description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Not Involved.description: The indicated response category was not involved in the response assessment.

MIBG_SCORE_TYPE.description: The type of response score provided in RESPONSE_MEASUREMENT_NUMERIC

MIBG SIOPEN Score.description: The semi-quantitative SIOPEN score evaluates skeletal meta-iodobenzylguanidine (mIBG) uptake on a 0–6 scale in 12 anatomical regions.

MIBG_SCORE.description: The numeric response of the MIBG score.
